title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes Individual Investment Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash contributions to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust in the U.S. exclusively for an individual, with specific requirements for contributions, trustee qualifications, and asset investments. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 outlines requirements for trust assets, prohibiting investment in collectibles and commingling with other property. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year, and distributions are generally included in gross income unless part of a qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution allows individuals to use payments from an investment account for qualified acquisition costs towards a principal residence. The maximum amount for such distributions is $20,000, and the basis of the residence is reduced by the distribution amount. The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not taxable. The account will be treated as belonging to the spouse after the transfer. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they no longer meet the criteria. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they no longer meet the criteria. If an individual engages in a prohibited transaction, the account will cease to be an individual investment account and be subject to taxes on unrelated business income. On the first day of any taxable year, paragraph (1) of subsection (c) is applied as if there were a distribution equal to the fair market value of all assets in the account. If an individual uses the account as security for a loan, that portion is treated as distributed to the individual. Rollover contributions are allowed if the amount is paid into another account within 60 days. Cost-of-Living Adjustment: The $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) increases annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $10, it is rounded to the nearest multiple. Custodial Accounts: These are treated as trusts if held by a bank or another entity approved by the Secretary. The custodial account, if held by a bank or approved entity, is treated as a trust. The trustee must report account details to the Secretary and the account holder as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. Individual investment account contributions are now deductible in arriving at adjusted gross income. Additionally, individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. "Individual investment accounts are now deductible in arriving at adjusted gross income and exempt from estate tax under SEC. 2046." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and exempt from estate tax. Special rules apply to transactions involving these accounts to avoid taxation under certain circumstances. Amendments have been made to sections related to failure to provide reports on individual investment accounts and the adjustment of basis for residences acquired through the use of these accounts. Amendments have been made to section 222 regarding the acquisition of residences using funds from individual investment accounts. Clerical amendments have been made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. Amendments to section 222 allow for the use of individual investment accounts to acquire residences. The table of sections has been updated to include new items related to individual investment accounts and disclaimers. These amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
